summary.p: The Kācikāṇṭam, The book of Kāci, that is Kāśī (Benares), is a Tamil version of the Kāśīkhaṇḍa of the late version of the Sanskrit Skandapurāṇa. The Kācikāṇṭam is the work of the Teṉkāci (Southern Kāśī) king Ativīrarāmapāṇṭiyaṉ, who ruled in the second half of the 16th century. See Raghavan (1960, p. 235). On Ativīrarāmapāṇṭiyaṉ, best known for his Naiṭatam, a Tamil version of the Sanskrit Naiṣadha by Harṣa, see Shulman (2012, pp. 155ff.).
The text is incomplete. See description below of U3 and mention of missing folios. It appears to be the collective work of several scribes, thus its inconsistent foliation.
Paratexts: marginal and in-text benedictions, title-page, invocation page, marginal chapter headers, in-text chapter completion statement, colophon, table of contents/total stanzas (U3, f295‒f297).

collation.desc: 1 folio = Title Page. No foliation. Double leaf. 400 x 30 mm. Verso blank. Shelfmark. Hand #1
1 folio = Kācikāṇṭam: Invocation. No foliation. Verso blank.

286 folios = Kācikāṇṭam: Mūlam. Tamil foliation 2‒297 (f77, f96‒f101, f131, f148, f178, f257 missing; three successive f70, two successive f76, two succesive f257). f1‒f2, f74‒f75, f76.1, f76.2 unblackened. 6 to 8 lines per page, by several hands (?), different from hand #1. The foliation discontinuity parallels, but not always, a textual discontinuity.

additions.desc: Stamp SOCIÉTÉ ASIATIQUE DON COLLECTION ARIEL (U1, f[1]r).

acquisition.p: Received, August 1st, 1866, from the Société Asiatique. See BnF, département des Manuscrits, inventaire 7 = Dons: manuscrits et imprimés documentaires, 1848-1895, no. 1192.

provenance.p: Owned by Édouard Ariel (1818-1854). Bequested by Édouard Ariel to Société Asiatique (Rosny 1868, p. 177).
